content.text: He places the metre rule on the pivot and then places block \(\mathbf{Q}\) with its centre at the \(95.0 \text{cm}\) mark
The student stated that it is difficult to place the mass accurately at the \(95.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Explain how the student could overcome this. You may draw a diagram to help your explanation
The student keeps block \(\mathbf{Q}\) at the \(95.0 \text{cm}\) mark and adjusts the position of the metre rule on the pivot until the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible
Describe a method to find the point at which the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(b / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to start your axes at the origin \((0, 0)\)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre rule using the equation \(M_{\mathrm{R}} = \frac{M}{(G - 1)}\) ,
where \(M = 20 \text{g}\). Record the value for \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment

The student determines the distance \(a\) between the centre of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and also the distance \(b\) between the centre of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the pivot
He repeats the procedure for positions of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\), \(85.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(75.0 \text{cm}\) marks. His results are shown in Table 1.1

Two students carry out the experiment correctly but with different values for the mass of block \(\mathbf{Q}\). One student obtains values of \(b\) that are larger than those obtained by the other student
State and explain whether the larger values of \(b\) are likely to produce a more accurate value for the mass of the metre rule
A student is determining the mass of a metre rule by a balancing method
He is using the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1
200 cm続 of hot water is poured into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) and the initial temperature rises to the value shown on thermometer \(\mathbf{A}\) in Fig. 2.1
In the first row of Table 2.1, record this temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) for time \(t = 0\)
100 cm続 of hot water is poured into beaker \(\mathbf{B}\). The temperature rises to the value shown on thermometer \(\mathbf{B}\) in Fig. 2.1
In the first row of the table, record this temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) for time \(t = 0\)

The temperatures \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water in each experiment at times \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\) are shown in the table
Complete the headings and the time column in the table

table.html:
beaker A
with 200 cm続 of water		beaker B
with 100 cm続 of water
\(t/\)\(\theta _{\mathrm {A}}/\)\(\theta _{\mathrm {B}}/\)

content.text: Describe one precaution which should be taken to ensure that the temperature readings in the experiment are as accurate as possible
Write a conclusion stating how the volume of water in the beaker affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by reference to the results
Using the results for \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average rate of cooling \(x_1\) for the first 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from the table and the equation
where \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at time 0 and at time 90 s
Include the unit for the rate of cooling
Using the results for \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average rate of cooling \(x_2\) in the last 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from the table and the equation
where \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at time 90 s and at time 180 s. Include the unit for the rate of cooling
A student suggests that it is important that the experiments with the two volumes of water should have the same starting temperatures
State whether your values for \(x_{1}\) and \(x_{2}\) support this suggestion. Justify your statement with reference to your results
statement
justification
Another student plans to investigate whether more thermal energy is lost from the water surface than from the sides of the beakers
Describe an experiment that could be done to investigate this
You may draw a diagram to help your description
Some students are investigating how the volume of water affects the rate at which water in a beaker cools
They are using the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
On Fig. 3.1, draw a voltmeter connected so that it measures the potential difference (p.d.) across lamp \(\mathbf{X}\)
The student uses the ammeter to measure the current in the circuit
Record the current \(I_{\mathrm{S}}\) in the circuit, as shown in Fig. 3.2
The student uses the voltmeter to measure the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{X}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) and then reconnects the voltmeter to measure the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{Y}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{Y}\)
Record the value of the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{X}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{X}\), shown in Fig. 3.3
Record the value of the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{Y}}\) across lamp \(\mathbf{Y}\), shown in Fig. 3.4
She then measures the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) across both lamps in series
Record the value of the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) across both lamps in series, shown in Fig. 3.5
A student suggests that \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) should be equal to \((V_{\mathrm{X}} + V_{\mathrm{Y}})\)
State whether the readings support this suggestion. Justify your statement with reference to the results
statement
justification
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of lamp \(\mathbf{X}\). Use the readings from **(b)** and **(c)**(i) and the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{X}}}{I_{\mathrm{S}}}\)
The circuit components are to be rearranged so that
lamps \(\mathbf{X}\) and \(\mathbf{Y}\) are connected in parallel
the ammeter measures the current in lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) only
the voltmeter measures the p.d. across the lamps
Draw a circuit diagram of this arrangement
The student sets up the circuit as described in **(e)(i)**
She measures and records the current in lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) and the p.d. across the lamps
She then calculates a new resistance \(R_{2}\) for lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) in this parallel circuit
The student notices that lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) is very bright in this parallel circuit, but it was dim in the series circuit in **(a)**
Suggest how temperature affects the resistance of a lamp
Justify your suggestion by reference to the value of \(R_{1}\) from **(d)** and the value of \(R_{2}\)
A student is investigating a circuit containing different lamps
She is using the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1
A student is investigating the factors that affect the size of the crater (hole) a ball makes when it is dropped into sand
Plan an experiment which would enable you to investigate one factor which might affect the size of the crater
The apparatus available includes
metal balls of different sizes a tray of sand
Write a plan for the experiment
In your plan you should:
揃 state which factor is being investigated,
揃 state the key variables that you would control,
揃 list any additional apparatus needed,
揃 explain briefly how you would carry out the experiment including what would be measured and how this would be done,
揃 state the precautions which should be taken to obtain reliable results,
揃 suggest a suitable graph which could be drawn from the results
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
